translation: Śākyamuni-sūtra

source_sentence: 比丘道略集
translation: Abridged Compilation of the Path of the Bhikṣu

source_sentence: 雀離寺師將沙彌下喻　聖王生九百九十九子喻　兄弟二人共為沙門喻　伎兒作種種伎喻　比丘被擯喻　目連與弟子下耆闍崛山喻　喜根喻　木師畫師喻　大迦葉婦因緣喻　兄好禪弟好多聞喻　羅云珠喻　龍昇天喻　於僧淨地大行喻　與貴人蹋唾喻　佛與弟子入舍衛乞食喻　醫師治王病喻　惡雨喻　阿修羅因緣喻　王子入山喻　鹿林喻　尸利求多喻　從婆羅門乞食喻　田舍人喻　呪龍喻　石當道喻　蛇頭尾共諍喻　捕鳥師喻　五百力士為沙門喻　三堅要喻　賣酪自存喻　五百賈客入海求寶喻　劫盡燒因緣喻　貴人為比丘尼因緣喻　草木皆可為藥喻　屠兒喻　王好布施喻　龍藏水喻　聖王得輪因緣喻　梵王長壽喻（一）昔雀離寺，有一長老比丘得羅漢道，將一沙彌時復來下入城遊觀，衣鉢大重，令沙彌擔隨從其後。
translation: 雀離寺師將沙彌下喻　聖王生九百九十九子喻　兄弟二人共為沙門喻　伎兒作種種伎喻　比丘被擯喻　目連與弟子下耆闍崛山喻　喜根喻　木師畫師喻　大迦葉婦因緣喻　兄好禪弟好多聞喻　羅云珠喻　龍昇天喻　於僧淨地大行喻　與貴人蹋唾喻　佛與弟子入舍衛乞食喻　醫師治王病喻　惡雨喻　阿修羅因緣喻　王子入山喻　鹿林喻　尸利求多喻　從婆羅門乞食喻　田舍人喻　呪龍喻　石當道喻　蛇頭尾共諍喻　捕鳥師喻　五百力士為沙門喻　三堅要喻　賣酪自存喻　五百賈客入海求寶喻　劫盡燒因緣喻　貴人為比丘尼因緣喻　草木皆可為藥喻　屠兒喻　王好布施喻　龍藏水喻　聖王得輪因緣喻　梵王長壽喻（一）昔雀離寺，有一長老比丘得羅漢道，將一沙彌時復來下入城遊觀，衣鉢大重，令沙彌擔隨從其後。

source_sentence: 沙彌道中便作是念：「人生世間無不受苦，欲免此苦當與何等道？」
translation: In the midst of his journey, the novice then thought, "There's nothing in this world that's not painful, so what path would he take to escape this pain?"

source_sentence: 作是思惟：「佛常讚歎菩薩為勝，我今當發菩薩心。」
translation: He had this thought, "The Buddha always praises the bodhisattvas as superior; now I will give rise to the bodhisattva aspiration."

source_sentence: 適作是念，其師即以知他心通照其所念，語沙彌言：「持衣鉢來。」
translation: When he thought this, his teacher then used his knowledge of other minds to perceive his thoughts and said to the novice, "Bring me your robe and bowl."

source_sentence: 沙彌持衣鉢授與其師，師語沙彌：「汝在前行。」
translation: The śrāmaṇer took the robe and bowl and gave it to his teacher, who said to him, "Go ahead and walk."

source_sentence: 沙彌適在前行，復作是念：「菩薩之道甚大勤苦，求頭與頭求眼與眼，此事極難非我所辦，不如早取羅漢疾得離苦。」
translation: As he was walking along, Śākyamuni again thought, "The path of the bodhisattva is so arduous that seeking head and head and seeking eyes and eyes is extremely difficult, and it's not something I can do; why don't I just take the arhat early and get rid of suffering quickly?"

source_sentence: 師復知其所念，語沙彌言：「汝擔衣鉢還從我後。」
translation: Again, the teacher knew what he was thinking and said to the novice, "Take your robe and bowl and return behind me."

source_sentence: 如是三反，沙彌怪愕不知何意。
translation: He said this three times, and the novice was surprised and didn't know what he meant.

source_sentence: 前至所止處，叉手白師請問其意。
translation: He went to the place where he had stopped, saluted his teacher with his palms together, and asked him what he thought.

source_sentence: 其師答曰：「汝於菩薩道三進故，我亦三反推汝在前；汝心三退故推汝在後。
translation: His teacher replied, "Because you've advanced three times on the bodhisattva path, I've also pushed you forward three times; because you've retreated three times in mind, I've pushed you backward.

source_sentence: 所以爾者，發菩薩心，其功德勝滿三千世界成就羅漢故也。」
translation: That's why, when you arouse the bodhisattva's aspiration, its merit is superior to that of an accomplished arhat who fills the 3,000 worlds."

source_sentence: （二）昔有轉輪聖王，先生九百九十九子，皆悉成大端正殊好，聰明黠慧兼有身力，或有具二十八相者，或具三十相者，或具三十一相者。
translation: (2) Once upon a time, there was a wheel-turning sage king who had 999 sons, all of whom became perfectly fine, intelligent, wise, and possessing physical strength, some with 28 marks, some with 30 marks, and some with 31 marks.

source_sentence: 末後一子始入母胎，處于惡露不淨之間。
translation: The last of those sons first entered his mother's womb and was caught in the midst of foul and impure dew.

source_sentence: 時有八部大力鬼神，鼓樂絃歌侍衛其母，王亦宣勅左右令具供養，種種嚴飾參倍於常。
translation: There are eight powerful demons with music and singing that guard his mother, and the king orders his attendants to make offerings with more than the usual array of finery.

source_sentence: 時人白王曰：「王先諸子，今皆成大，智慧聰徹身相殊妙，王心平然未常欣慶。
translation: The men then said to the king, "Now, all of the king's former sons have become great, and their bodies are marvelous in terms of their wisdom and penetration, which the king has yet to rejoice over with equanimity.

source_sentence: 今此一子始處母胎，有何奇特供給異常耶？」
translation: Now, what's so special about this one child who was first born in his mother's womb that makes offerings that are out of the ordinary?"

source_sentence: 時王答曰：「吾大子等雖才美過人，未有堪任登大位者，吾末後子若生長大，必當堪任嗣大位也。」
translation: The king then answered, "Although my eldest sons are more talented than most people, none of them are qualified to ascend to the great throne; if my latter sons grow large, they surely will be qualified to succeed to the great throne."

source_sentence: 時聖王者喻如佛也，諸大子者喻如下二乘也，末後處子喻菩薩也。
translation: The holy king then was a metaphor for the Buddha, the older sons were a metaphor for the following two vehicles, and the younger sons were a metaphor for the bodhisattvas.

source_sentence: 言菩薩雖雜塵垢，但能發大意者，必為諸佛所念，天龍鬼神皆興敬愛之也。
translation: It means that a bodhisattva who, though dusty and defiled, can nonetheless muster great resolve will be on the minds of the buddhas, and gods, dragons, and spirits will revere him.

source_sentence: （三）昔迦葉佛時有兄弟二人，出家俱為沙門，兄好持戒坐禪，一心求道而不好布施；弟好布施修福而喜破戒。
translation: (3) Once, when Kāśyapa Buddha was born, there were two brothers who left home and became ascetics. The older brother was fond of observing precepts and sitting in meditation, single-mindedly seeking the path but not generosity; the younger brother was fond of generosity and cultivating virtue but delighted in breaking precepts.

source_sentence: 釋迦文出世，其兄值佛出家修道即得羅漢，而獨薄福，常患衣食不充，與諸伴等遊行乞食，常獨不飽而還。
translation: When Śākyamuni appeared in the world, his brother became a arhat when the Buddha left home and cultivated, but he was alone in his weak fortune, often suffering from a lack of adequate clothing and food, and often returned alone without having enough to eat when he and his companions marched around begging for food.

source_sentence: 其弟生象中，為象多力能却怨敵，為國王所愛，以好金銀珍寶瓔珞，其身封數百戶邑，供給此象隨其所須。
translation: His younger brother was born among elephants, and he was so powerful that he was able to defeat his enemies and was loved by the king, who gave him a fortune in gold, silver, jewelry, and jewelry, and he was given hundreds of towns and villages to offer to the elephant as he desired.

source_sentence: 時兄比丘者值世大儉，遊行乞食七日不得，末後得少麤食殆得存命。
translation: That older monk was so frugal that he traveled for seven days begging for food, but at the end he got a little coarse food and was able to survive.

source_sentence: 先知此象是前世兄弟，便往詣象前，手捉象耳而語之言：「我與汝俱有罪也。」
translation: Knowing that this elephant was a brother from a previous life, he went up to the elephant, grabbed it by the ear, and said, "We're both guilty, you and I."

source_sentence: 象便思惟比丘語，即得自識宿命，見前世因緣，象便愁憂不復飲食。
translation: The elephant then considered the monk's words and realized that he knew his past life and saw the causes and conditions from previous lives.

source_sentence: 象子怖懼便往白王言：「象不復飲食，不知何意？」
translation: Frightened, the elephant's son went to the king and said, "What do you mean the elephant won't eat or drink again?"

source_sentence: 王問象子：「先有人犯此象不？」
translation: The king asked Elephant Boy, "Did someone before you violate this elephant?"

source_sentence: 象子答王言：「無他異人，唯見一沙門來至象邊，須臾便去耳。」
translation: The elephant replied to the king, "There's no other person, except for an ascetic who came to the elephant and left after a short while."

source_sentence: 王即遣人四出覓此沙門。
translation: The king then sent people out to search for this ascetic.

source_sentence: 有人於林樹間得，便攝此沙門將詣王前，王問沙門言：「至我象邊何所道說？」
translation: When someone found him among the trees, he gathered the monk and brought him to the king, who asked him, "What did he tell me about coming to my elephant?"

source_sentence: 沙門答王言：「無所多說，我直語象言：『我與汝俱有罪耳。』」
translation: The ascetic answered the king, "There's nothing more to say. I simply said to the elephant, 'I'm guilty with you.'"

source_sentence: 時沙門便向王具說前世因緣事，王意便悟，即放此沙門令還所止。
translation: The monk then explained to the king exactly what happened in previous lives in terms of causes and conditions, and the king's mind was immediately enlightened.

source_sentence: （四）昔有伎兒作種種伎樂，從一富長者乞牛，長者了無與心，故語之言：「汝能如是勤作伎樂晝夜不息滿一歲者，我當與汝牛。」
translation: (4) Once, a musician who was engaged in various kinds of music begged a rich man for a cow, and the man knew better than to give it to him, so he said, "If you can thus work hard at music day and night for a year, I'll give you a cow."

source_sentence: 伎兒答言：「能。」
translation: The musician replied, "Yes."

source_sentence: 復語主人：「能聽不？」
translation: Again, he said to his master, "Can you hear me?"

source_sentence: 長者亦言：「能。」
translation: The elder also said, "Yes."

source_sentence: 於是伎兒聞是歡喜，一心作樂，三日三夜未甞休懈。
translation: The musician then rejoiced at what he heard, and his mind was focused on having fun for three days and nights without laziness.

source_sentence: 長者厭聽已，即勅子弟牽牛與之。
translation: After he heard this, the elder got tired of it and ordered his disciple to bring him a cow.

source_sentence: 此喻行道作福者，不以劫數為遠，精勤彌篤報至彌疾，不必皆經爾數劫也。
translation: This is a metaphor for someone who practices the path to make merit, who doesn't look back on eons as distant and whose diligence and dedication will be rewarded with lasting success, and who doesn't have to go through all of these eons.

source_sentence: （五）昔有一比丘被擯，懊惱悲歎涕哭而行，道逢一鬼，此鬼犯法亦為毘沙門天王所擯。
translation: (5) Once, a monk was expelled, upset, saddened, and weeping as he walked along the path, and he met a ghost who had violated the Dharma and was also taken in by the god Vaiśravaṇa.

source_sentence: 時鬼問比丘言：「汝有何事涕哭而行？」
translation: The demon then asked the monk, "What's the matter with you, weeping and walking?"

source_sentence: 比丘答曰：「我犯僧事，眾僧所擯，一切檀越供養盡失，又惡名聲流布遠近，是故愁歎涕泣耳。」
translation: The monk replied, "I've violated the saṃgha's rules, been rejected by the saṃgha, lost all the donations from the patrons, and had a bad reputation that spread far and wide, so I'm sad and weep."

source_sentence: 鬼語比丘言：「我能令汝滅惡名聲大得供養。
translation: The demon said to the monk, "I can rid you of your bad reputation and greatly enhance your offerings.

source_sentence: 汝可便立我左肩上，我當擔汝虛空中行，人但見汝而不見我身。
translation: You can then stand on my left shoulder, and I'll carry you through the sky so that people only see you and don't see my body.

source_sentence: 汝若大得供養，當先與我。」
translation: If you greatly obtain offerings, you must first give them to me."

source_sentence: 彼鬼即時擔此比丘，於先被擯聚落上虛空中行。
translation: The demon then carried the monk up into the sky above the village where he had been rebuffed.

source_sentence: 時聚落人見皆驚怪，謂其得道，轉相謂言：「眾僧無狀抂擯得道之人。」
translation: The people of the village were surprised to see him, saying, "They say he's attained the way, and they turn to each other, saying, 'Monks, you have no shape to disparage someone who's attained the way.'"

source_sentence: 時聚落人皆詣此寺呵責眾僧，即迎此比丘住於寺內，遂大得供養。
translation: The tribesmen then all went to this temple, rebuked the monks, welcomed the monk to live there, and made great offerings.

source_sentence: 此比丘隨所得衣食諸物，輒先與鬼不違本要，此鬼異日復擔此比丘遊行空中。
translation: Whatever food and clothing he had, the monk gave to the ghost first, not disobeying the original request, and the ghost would carry the monk through the air again some day.

source_sentence: 正值毘沙門天王官屬，鬼見司官甚大驚怖，捐棄比丘絕力而走，此比丘遂墮地而死，身首碎爛。
translation: It was during an official of the Vaiśravaṇa god king that the ghost, terrified at the sight of the official, abandoned the monk and left without strength, so the monk fell to the ground and died, his body and head broken off.

source_sentence: 此喻行者宜應自修所向，不應恃託豪勢，一旦傾覆，與彼無異也。
translation: This is an example of how practitioners should cultivate what they're aiming for and shouldn't rely on powerful people who, once tilted, would be no different from them.

source_sentence: （六）昔目連與諸弟子俱，從耆闍崛山下到王舍城乞食。
translation: (6) Once, Maudgalyāyana and his disciples went down from Mount Gṛdhrakūṭa to Rājagṛha to solicit alms.

source_sentence: 目連於道中仰視虛空囅然而笑。
translation: In the middle of the road, Māraṇī looked up into the sky and laughed aloud.

source_sentence: 其弟子問：「何因緣笑？」
translation: His disciples asked, "What's the reason for that smile?"

source_sentence: 目連答曰：「卿欲知者，須還到佛所，可更問也。」
translation: Maudgalyāyana answered, "If you want to know, you must go back to the Buddha, and you can ask him again."

source_sentence: 於是乞食訖還到佛所，其弟子更問目連向所笑意，目連答曰：「我見上虛空中有一餓鬼，身極長大其狀醜惡，有七枚熱鐵丸，從口中入直下過去，既下過已還從口入，舉體火然苦痛婉轉，絕倒復起起復還倒，是故笑耳。
translation: After he finished his begging for food and returned to the Buddha, his disciple asked Maudgalyāyana what he was smiling about, and Maudgalyāyana replied, "I saw a hungry ghost in the sky with a body that was extremely long and large and ugly in shape, and it had seven hot iron balls that went straight down through its mouth and went right past it.

source_sentence: 非我獨見，佛亦見也。」
translation: I'm not the only one who sees this; the Buddha also sees it."

source_sentence: 弟子問言：「以何因緣受苦如是？」
translation: The disciple asked, "What are the causes and conditions for suffering like this?"

source_sentence: 目連答曰：「汝自以是問佛世尊。」
translation: Maudgalyāyana answered, "This is how you ask the Bhagavān."

source_sentence: 其弟子即時白佛問其因緣。
translation: His disciple then immediately asked the Buddha about the cause and conditions.

source_sentence: 時佛答言：「此餓鬼者前世曾為沙彌，時世極儉，以豆為食，沙彌者為眾僧行食，至其師前偏多七枚豆，以是罪故，受餓鬼身苦毒如是。」
translation: The Buddha then answered, "In a previous life, this hungry ghost was a novice monk who was extremely frugal and fed on beans.

source_sentence: 佛言：「我亦常見，所以不說，恐人不信得極大罪也。」
translation: The Buddha said, "I too often see this, so I don't tell it because I'm afraid people won't believe it and get a very serious sin."

source_sentence: 此喻佛說般若，不信誹謗，其罪重於五逆，受地獄極苦也。
translation: This is a metaphor for the Buddha's teaching of prajñā, which is a greater misdeed than the five heinous crimes and results in extreme suffering in hell.

source_sentence: （七）在昔過世無量塵數之劫，時有菩薩名曰喜根，於大眾中講摩訶衍。
translation: (7) In a bygone era of measureless dust eons, there was a bodhisattva named Śrīgupta who taught Mahāyāna among the masses.

source_sentence: 文殊師利時為凡人，出家修道專精苦行，行十二頭陀福度一切，遇值講法，因而過聽喜根菩薩說實相法，言婬怒癡與道不異，亦即是道亦是涅槃。
translation: At the time, Mañjuśrī was an ordinary man who had left home, cultivated austerities, and performed twelve ascetic practices to merit all sentient beings when he came across a Dharma talk.

source_sentence: 文殊爾時聞而不信即便捨去。
translation: Hearing this, Mañjuśrī didn't believe it and even abandoned it.

source_sentence: 到喜根弟子家，為說惡露不淨之法，喜根弟子即時難曰：「無所有者法之真也，諸法皆空，云何當有淨與不淨？」
translation: When he went to the joyful root's disciple's house and taught him the awful, dewy, and impure Dharma, the joyful root's disciple immediately objected, saying, "There's no owner of the truth of the Dharma, and all things are empty, so how could there be purity and impurity?"

source_sentence: 頭陀比丘默然無對，含瞋心內，遂成憤結。
translation: The monk Śuddhodana remained silent and unanswered, and he became fettered with anger within his mind.

source_sentence: 時喜根弟子說七十偈讚實相法，頭陀比丘聞一偈，瞋恚生一增，竟七十偈，瞋恚七十增。
translation: When the joyful disciple spoke seventy verses praising the true character of the Dharma, the monk heard one verse, and his anger grew by one, and after finishing seventy verses, his anger grew by seventy.

source_sentence: 說偈適竟，地即劈裂，無擇泥梨於是悉現，頭陀比丘即墮其中，過無量劫罪畢乃出，然後乃知不信妙法其罪重也。
translation: When the verse was finished, the ground split open and the nirvāṇa of no choice was fully revealed, into which the monk Śuddhodana immediately fell, and he emerged after finishing his misdeeds for measureless eons.

source_sentence: 後為比丘，專精學問，得大智慧解空第一。
translation: Later, he became a monk who concentrated on study and attained great wisdom and the highest level of understanding of emptiness.

source_sentence: 此喻明佛說般若，不信誹謗，今雖有損，後大益也。
translation: This metaphor shows that the Buddha taught prajñā and didn't believe in slander; although it's a disservice now, it'll be a great benefit later.

source_sentence: （八）昔北天竺有一木師大巧，作一木女端正無雙，衣帶嚴飾與世女無異，亦來亦去亦能行酒看客，唯不能語耳。
translation: (8) Once, there was a woodworker in northern India who was quite skilled at creating a wooden woman who was perfectly proportioned and beautiful, was dressed and adorned like ordinary women, and could come and go as well as serve wine to visitors, except that she couldn't speak.

source_sentence: 時南天竺有一畫師，亦善能畫，木師聞之，作好飲食即請畫師。
translation: There was a painter in southern India who was also a good painter. When the woodworker heard about this, he prepared a meal and invited the painter.

source_sentence: 畫師既至，便使木女行酒擎食從旦至夜，畫師不知謂是真女，欲心極盛念之不忘。
translation: When the painter arrived, he asked the wood girl to serve him wine and food from dawn until dusk. The painter didn't know that she was a real girl, but his desire for her was so great that he couldn't forget her.

source_sentence: 時日以暮木師入宿，亦留畫師令住止，以此木女立侍其側，便語客言：「故留此女可共宿也。」
translation: When the time came for the painter to stay overnight at sunset, he also asked the painter to stay overnight with this wooden girl standing by his side, and then he said to the guest, "So we can leave this girl overnight with him."

source_sentence: 主人已入，木女立在燈邊，客即呼之而女不來，客謂此女羞故不來，便前以手牽之，乃知是木，便自慚愧，心念口言：「主人誑我，我當報之。」
translation: After the master entered, the wooden girl was standing by the lamp, and the guest called out to her, but she didn't come. The guest said that the girl was ashamed and therefore wouldn't come, so he took her by the hand and realized that she was a log.

source_sentence: 於是畫師復作方便，即於壁上畫作己像，所著被服與身不異，以繩繫頸狀似絞死，畫作蠅鳥著其口啄，作已閉戶自入床下。
translation: The master then again made it easy for him to paint a picture of himself on the wall, wearing clothing not unlike his own, tied a rope around his neck in the shape of a hanging woman, and painted a fly in his mouth, pecking at him, and then closed the door and put himself under the bed.

source_sentence: 天明主人出，見戶未開，即向中觀，唯見壁上絞死客像，主人大怖便謂實死，即破戶入以刀斷繩。
translation: When the master emerged at dawn, he saw that the door hadn't been opened, so he looked inside and saw only the image of the guest being strangled to death on the wall. The master was terrified, so he assumed he was really dead and broke through the door to enter and cut the rope with a knife.

source_sentence: 於是畫師從床下出，木師大羞。
translation: The master then got out from under the bed and was greatly embarrassed by the wood painter.

source_sentence: 畫師即言：「汝能誑我，我能誑汝，客主情畢，不相負也。」
translation: The master then said, "You can deceive me, and I can deceive you; the guest and the master have finished their relationship, so they won't be at odds with each other."

source_sentence: 二人相謂：「世人相誑惑，孰異於此？」
translation: The two of them said to each other, "Which one of the world's deceivers is different from this?"

source_sentence: 時彼二人信知誑惑，各捨所親愛出家修道。
translation: Believing and knowing that they were deluded, they each abandoned their loved ones and left home to practice.

source_sentence: 迦葉本生因緣事
translation: Kāśyapa's previous life was a matter of causes and conditions.

source_sentence: （九）迦葉父者名曰尼俱律陀，摩竭國人也，出自婆羅門種，宿命福德生世大富，其珍奇寶物於彼國第一，比國王財富千分少一耳。
translation: (9) Kāśyapa's father was named Nigrodha, a native of the country of Maghreb who came from the Brāhmaṇa lineage and was born into a life of great fortune, where his treasures were the most valuable in that country, less than a thousandth of the king's wealth.

source_sentence: 夫婦孤獨乏無兒息，近在舍側有大樹神，時彼夫婦為欲有兒故求彼樹神，三生祭祠歲歲不絕，故其所求，永無本末，其人遂忿便急與之，期告樹神曰：「我更盡心七日相事，若復無驗當揃伐汝，棄都道頭以火燒之。」
translation: When that man and wife were orphaned and had no children, there was a large tree god near their house.

source_sentence: 樹神聞其言甚大驚怖，不知何方令得子息，即便上告息意天王，具以事情向天王說。
translation: When the tree god heard what he said, he was terrified and didn't know how he'd gotten his child to stop, so he went up to the god Xiyi and told him exactly what had happened.

source_sentence: 息意天王即將樹神詣天帝釋，以其所告白天帝釋。
translation: King Sthiramati then sent the tree god to Indra and told Indra what he had told him.

source_sentence: 釋即以天眼觀欲界中，未有堪任為彼子者，帝釋便告梵天王，具以事情向梵王說。
translation: He then observed with his divine eye that there was no one in the desire realm who could be his son.

source_sentence: 梵王即以天眼觀視其界，見一梵天臨當壽終，便告之曰：「汝可下生閻浮提，為摩竭國尼俱律陀婆羅門作子。」
translation: The king then looked into that realm with his divine eye and saw a Brahma god who was about to reach the end of his life and told him, "You may be born down in Jambudvīpa as a son of the Brahmin of Maghreb."

source_sentence: 梵天對曰：「婆羅門者多諸邪見，我若下生，不能為其作子。」
translation: The Brahma replied, "Brāhmaṇas have many mistaken views, so if I were to descend into his life, I wouldn't be able to be his son."

source_sentence: 梵王答曰：「婆羅門宿時大德，欲界眾生無有堪任為作子者，汝若往生，吾當勅天帝釋，令擁護汝，不使中道墮邪見也。」
translation: The king replied, "Bhāramitā was a great virtuous man of long ago, and there are no sentient beings in the desire realm who would be capable of being their sons.

source_sentence: 梵天曰：「諾，不違聖教。」
translation: The Brahmadeva said, "Promise, I won't disobey the noble teaching."

source_sentence: 時天帝釋即還欲界，具以此意告勅樹神，樹神歡喜還告長者：「勿憂勿懼勿見瞋恨！
translation: Śakra then returned to the desire realm and gave this advice to the tree god, who rejoiced and returned to the elder, "Don't be sad, don't be afraid, and don't look at him with hatred!

source_sentence: 却後七日必令有子。」
translation: After the seventh day, she'll surely have a child."

source_sentence: 如其所言七日已滿，其婦人便覺有娠，滿十月已其子乃生，軀身金色而有光明。
translation: After the seven days had passed as he had said, the woman then felt pregnant, and after the tenth month had passed, her son was born with a golden body and a bright light.

source_sentence: 相師占曰：「此兒宿福有大威德，志力清遠不貪世務，若後出家必登聖道。」
translation: The fortune teller said, "This child has been blessed from long ago with great authority, a clear determination, and no desire for worldly tasks; if he later leaves home, he'll surely attain the noble path."

source_sentence: 父母聞之復大愁憂，恐兒長大棄吾出家，以何方便當制止之？
translation: When his parents hear this, they are again greatly distressed, fearing that their son will grow up and abandon us to leave home.

source_sentence: 復自思惟：「欲界所重遂在美色，當為擇取端正好女以繫之耳。」
translation: "Again, he thought, 'The desire realm focuses on beauty, so I should choose a decent, good woman to tie him down.'

source_sentence: 至年十五欲為娶婦，迦葉聞之甚大愁憂，語父母言：「我志樂清淨，不須婦也。」
translation: When he reached the age of fifteen and wanted to marry a woman, Kāśyapa was greatly distressed when he heard about it and said to his parents, "I want to be pure, so I don't need a wife."

source_sentence: 迦葉辭至三，父母答如初。
translation: Kāśyapa said up to three times, but his parents answered as before.

source_sentence: 於時迦葉語父母言：「我不用凡女人為婦也，若能得紫金色女端正無比，爾乃取之耳。」
translation: Kāśyapa then said to his parents, "I don't need an ordinary woman to be my wife; if I could get a purple-gold woman who's correct and has no equal, then I would take her."

source_sentence: 所以然者，欲必令此事不可辦故也。
translation: That's why they wanted to make sure that it wouldn't be possible.

source_sentence: 於是其父母召諸婆羅門，令循行國中，其有女子身體金色具足女相端正殊好，爾乃取之。
translation: His parents then summoned the brāhmaṇas and told them to go around the country and find a woman with a golden body and the features of a woman of excellent appearance, and then they would take her.

source_sentence: 於是諸婆羅門設權策鑄作金女神，顏貌端正光色微妙，舁天像行，從國至國高聲大唱：「諸有女人得見金女神禮拜供養者，後出嫁時當得好聟，體黃金色顏貌殊妙智慧無比。」
translation: The brāhmaṇas then set out to forge a gold goddess with a beautiful face and subtle radiance who would raise a heavenly image and walk from country to country, shouting, "If any woman who sees the gold goddess venerates, worships, and makes offerings to her, she'll be given a good cherry when she gets married, and her body will be yellow-gold with a beautiful appearance and unsurpassed wisdom."

source_sentence: 聚落國邑諸有女人，聞此唱者莫不虛心，皆出奉迎禮拜供養。
translation: All the women in the villages and towns who heard this announcement were so open-minded that they all went out to welcome her, venerate her, and make offerings to her.

source_sentence: 唯有一女軀體金色端正殊好，獨處閑室不肯出迎。
translation: Only one woman, whose body was golden and perfectly fine, went into a private room alone and refused to go out to greet her.

source_sentence: 諸女諫曰：「其有見金女神者皆得如願，汝何以獨不出迎？」
translation: The women remonstrated, saying, "Everyone who sees the golden goddess gets what they want, so why don't you go out to greet her alone?"

source_sentence: 答曰：「吾志閑淨，不好餘願也。」
translation: They replied, "My intention is quiet, so I don't have any other vows."

source_sentence: 諸女復曰：「雖無所願，暫共一觀當復何損？」
translation: The women then said, "Even though we don't have any vows, what harm would it do to share a single view for a while?"

source_sentence: 爾時諸女遂共此女出到金女神前。
translation: The women then joined her and she went out to the goddess of gold.

source_sentence: 此女既到光色明淨，映奪金女神光金不復現。
translation: When she arrived, her radiance was so clear and bright that it reflected off the gold goddess's radiance and gold didn't reappear.

source_sentence: 於是諸婆羅門見已，還報長者具足廣說。
translation: After they saw this, the brāhmaṇas returned to the elder and explained it in detail.

source_sentence: 於是長者即遣媒人，到其女家宣長者意，其女父母先亦聞迦葉名，敬承往意遂相然可。
translation: The elder then sent a matchmaker to the woman's home to explain the elder's wishes, and her parents, who had heard of Kāśyapa's name earlier, respectfully acknowledged his intentions and approved.

source_sentence: 彼女聞之甚大愁憒，父母所逼事不獲已，遂便適長者家。
translation: When she heard that, she was greatly distressed, and since she hadn't been able to get over what her parents had forced her to do, she went to the elder's house.

source_sentence: 既到與迦葉相見，二人相對志各凝潔，雖為夫婦了無恩情。
translation: When they arrived and met Kāśyapa, their intentions were each quite pure, even though they were husband and wife and had no affection for each other.

source_sentence: 其婦遂與迦葉結誓：「我與君等，各處異房，要不相觸。」
translation: The woman then made a vow with Kāśyapa, "We'll each go to a different room, and we won't touch each other."

source_sentence: 爾時夫婦各處一房，其父伺迦葉出時，密遣人壞去一房，唯令與婦共同一室，雖共同室而復異床。
translation: While the husband and wife were each in a separate room, his father waited for Kāśyapa to leave and secretly sent someone to destroy one of the rooms, making it so that he and the woman would share the same room, even though they shared the same room but had different beds.

source_sentence: 其父尋復遣人持一床去，於是夫婦雖共同床，其婦更與夫誓：「我若眠時君當經行，君眠時我當經行。」
translation: The father then sent another man to take a bed away, and although the husband and wife shared the same bed, the woman vowed to her husband, "When I sleep, you will walk, and when you sleep, I will walk."

source_sentence: 時其婦臥，一臂垂地，有大毒蛇欲來嚙之，迦葉見已有慈愍心，持衣裹手舉著床上。
translation: When the woman was lying down with one arm hanging to the ground, a large venomous snake tried to bite her, but Kāśyapa, having seen it, compassionately wrapped his robe around his hand and put it on the bed.

source_sentence: 尋時驚覺，便大瞋怒語迦葉言：「我先有要，如何相犯？」
translation: When she looked into it, she was startled and said to Kāśyapa in anger, "I had a request, how could I have violated it?"

source_sentence: 迦葉報言：「汝臂落地，毒蛇欲嚙，是故相救，非故觸也。」
translation: Kāśyapa replied, "Your arm fell to the ground, and a viper wanted to bite it; therefore, we saved it, not touched it for that reason."

source_sentence: 毒蛇故在邊住，指而示之，其婦乃悟。
translation: The viper was therefore standing nearby, so he pointed at it and showed it to the woman, who then realized it.

source_sentence: 於是夫婦自相與議：「我等何不出家修道？」
translation: The couple then talked to each other, saying, "Why don't we leave home and train as monks?"

source_sentence: 時夫婦二人遂辭父母，俱共出家山澤行道。
translation: The husband and wife then left their parents and left home together to practice on a mountain swamp.

source_sentence: 時有婆羅門將五百弟子亦住此山，見迦葉夫婦便生毀謗言：「出家之法宜各貞潔，何有夫婦共相隨理？」
translation: Then, a Brāhmaṇa who had 500 disciples staying on this mountain also saw Kāśyapa and his wife and denigrated them, saying, "It's appropriate for each monk and wife to be chaste, so why would a husband and wife follow each other?"

source_sentence: 於時迦葉便捨其婦，以五百兩金貿緻衲衣，別處一林；其婦即依止婆羅門求為弟子。
translation: Kāśyapa then abandoned his wife and gave her five hundred taels of gold to make a robe and take her to a different forest; she then relied on the Brāhmaṇas and asked to become a disciple.

source_sentence: 婆羅門五百弟子，見此女人形色端正日日行婬，此女人不得自在，遂不能堪，便告其師，師便為之戒約弟子，令節其所欲。
translation: When the five hundred disciples of the Brāhmaṇa saw this woman in proper form and engaging in sexual misconduct day in and day out, the woman couldn't get comfortable, so they told their master, who then instructed the disciples to abide by the precepts and restrain their desires.

source_sentence: 迦葉後值佛出世，聞法受化即得羅漢，聞其本妻在梵志邊，便將來詣佛。
translation: When the Buddha appeared in the world, Kāśyapa heard about the teaching and was transformed into a arhat. He heard that his wife was near the Brahmā, so he came to visit the Buddha.

source_sentence: 佛為說法得羅漢，頭髮自落法服在身，成比丘尼，遊行教化。
translation: The Buddha taught the Dharma and made him a arhat, so he took off his hair and put on the Dharma robe, became a bhikṣuṇī, and marched around teaching.

source_sentence: 正值波斯匿王大會，諸比丘尼便得入王宮裏，教化諸夫人皆令持一日齋。
translation: It was during King Prasenajit's assembly that the bhikṣuṇīs were allowed to enter the king's palace and instruct the ladies to observe the one-day fast.

source_sentence: 王暮還宮命諸夫人，皆云持齋無肯來者，王便大瞋怒語使人言：「誰教諸夫人齋？」
translation: When the king returned to the palace at sunset and asked the ladies to observe the fast, they all said they had no one willing to come, so the king became angry and told his messengers, "Who taught the ladies to observe the fast?"

source_sentence: 使人答言：「某甲比丘尼！」
translation: The messenger replied, "Some bhikṣuṇī!"

source_sentence: 王便呼來，令九十日代諸夫人受婬欲。
translation: The king then summoned them here and ordered them to take the place of the ladies for ninety days in order to indulge in sexual desire.

source_sentence: 此皆是昔之因緣誓願所追還也，故使雖得羅漢不能相免。
translation: These were all causes and conditions from the past that were vowed to be returned, so even though they had attained arhatship, they couldn't be spared.

source_sentence: （一〇）昔有兄弟二人出家學道，兄常念行禪精專修道，得羅漢果六通清徹。
translation: (10) Once there were two brothers who left home and trained on the path. The older brother was always mindful of practicing meditation and concentrated on cultivation, attaining the fruit of the arhat and clearing the six supernormal powers.

source_sentence: 其弟常念廣學多聞，好賣名聲欲己自榮。
translation: The younger brother was always mindful of his extensive training and learning, and he liked to sell his reputation in order to win it for himself.

source_sentence: 其兄常曉喻弟言：「人身難得，佛世難值，既得人身，宜曼時為。」
translation: The older brother always instructed the younger brother, "The human body is difficult to attain, and the Buddha's life is difficult to attain; once you attain the human body, it's better to cultivate it at the right time."

source_sentence: 弟語兄言：「須得廣學具足三藏堪任人師，爾乃行禪。」
translation: The disciple told his brother, "You must study widely and fully the Tripiṭaka to become a human teacher before you can practice meditation."

source_sentence: 兄復為弟廣宣非常之義，出息不反便屬後世，弟故執其本意不肯隨教。
translation: He then explained the extraordinary meaning in detail for him, saying that he would belong to the afterlife if he didn't retreat, so he stuck to his original intention and refused to follow the teaching.

source_sentence: 未久之間弟得篤疾，良醫數十不能加救，醫知其必死小小捨去。
translation: Before long, he had a serious illness that couldn't be helped by dozens of good doctors, who knew he would surely die and abandoned him.

source_sentence: 弟便恐怖自知當死，語其兄言：「在昔愚短不用兄教，今將命終知適何道？」
translation: Then, terrified, he knew he was going to die and said to his brother, "In the past, I was foolish and didn't use your teaching; now, as I approach the end of my life, I wonder what path I should follow."

source_sentence: 涕淚交流向兄悔過，未久之間其人命終，兄即入定觀其所趣，見處長者胎。
translation: He exchanged tears and confessions with his brother. Before long, his life ended, and he entered into meditation, observed his destination, and saw the elder's birth.

source_sentence: 彼長者家接近寺廟，兄便數詣此家求作善知識，欲度其弟故。
translation: The elder's family was near a temple, so the brother went there several times to seek to become a good teacher and to save his younger brother.

source_sentence: 長者兒始年三歲，便持布施為作弟子，至四歲乳母抱詣師所住寺，寺在山上累石作道，乳母抱兒不堅失手落地，頭側石上腦出而死。
translation: When he was four years old, his nursing mother carried him to the temple where the master lived. The temple was on a hill, and there were rocks piled up to make a path.

source_sentence: 兒臨終時便生惡念，恨其抱不堅以致此禍，因起瞋恚命終徑墮大地獄中。
translation: When the child was about to die, he gave rise to bad thoughts, hating his lack of firmness in embracing him for causing this misfortune, and as a result, he became angry and fell into great hell at the end of his life.

source_sentence: 兄復入定觀之，見生地獄，於是慨歎此必了矣，地獄苦切難可度也，諸佛尚不能奈何，何況我乎？
translation: When he returned to meditation and looked at him, he saw that he had been born in hell, and then he lamented that this would surely be the end, that the suffering of hell is so severe that it's difficult to escape, and that the buddhas are still unable to help, so why should I?

source_sentence: 此喻人者名聲不能修禪後墮惡道，雖父兄之親不能救也。
translation: This is a metaphor for a person whose reputation prevents them from cultivating meditation and then falls into a bad destiny, even though their father's and brother's relatives can't save them.

source_sentence: （一一）羅云珠者，舍利弗弟子也，本曾奪辟支佛食，以是罪故生餓鬼中，無量劫受苦。
translation: (11) This is Lāwunju, a disciple of Śāriputra who once stole food from Pārśva and was born among hungry ghosts because of that sin, suffering for measureless eons.

source_sentence: 畢餓鬼身生人中，五百世受飢餓罪，以末後身值佛在世，出家學道服三法衣，遊行乞食無肯施者，或五日或七日不得。
translation: After finishing his life as a hungry ghost, he was born among humans and suffered from hunger for 500 lifetimes. In his final lifetime, he was born during the Buddha's lifetime, left home, trained on the path, put on the three dharma robes, and marched around begging for food that no one would give, whether it was for five or seven days.

source_sentence: 目連愍之乞食持與，適墮鉢中為大鳥搏去。
translation: Mucilin took pity on him and begged for food to take with him, but he fell into a bowl and was wrestled away by a large bird.

source_sentence: 舍利弗乞食施之，適入鉢中變成泥土。
translation: Śāriputra begged for food and gave it to him, but it fell into his bowl and turned to mud.

source_sentence: 大迦葉乞食施之，適持向口，口即時合無有入處。
translation: Mahākāśyapa begged for food to give and gave it to his mouth, but his mouth immediately closed and there was no place to put it.

source_sentence: 佛以食施，以大悲力故，即得入口氣味殊特，復以種種方便兼為說法。
translation: With this gift of food, the Buddha, through the power of his great compassion, was able to give his mouth a distinctive taste and also preach the Dharma with various skillful means.

source_sentence: 時羅云珠聞上妙法悲喜交集，一心思惟得應真道。
translation: When Luoyunzhu heard about the above-mentioned wonderful teaching, his compassion and joy were combined, and he focused his thoughts on attaining the true path.

source_sentence: （一二）有龍昇天降于大雨，雨落天宮即成七寶，雨落人中皆為潤澤，落餓鬼身上變成大火舉身燒然，俱是一雨而所墮變異也。
translation: (12) A dragon ascends to heaven and sends down a deluge of rain, which falls on the heavenly palace and becomes seven treasures, falls on humans and moistens them, and falls on hungry ghosts and turns them into a great fire that burns their bodies, all because of the variation in what falls from a single rain.

source_sentence: 此二事明眾形無定質，隨罪福之所感也。
translation: These two things show that there's no set quality to the forms of multitudes, and they follow the effects of sins and fortune.

source_sentence: （一三）外國有住處，眾中有一道人，當眾僧淨地大行，更有一道人性多瞋恚，便以舌舐之用示眾人。
translation: (13) There's a place in a foreign country where there's one person in the congregation who, while the saṃgha is engaged in great practice on the pure ground, there's another person who's full of anger and shows the crowd by licking their tongues.

source_sentence: 雖欲彰人之罪，不知自惡其口。
translation: Although he wanted to show people's sins, he didn't know that he was bad-mouthing them.

source_sentence: 此明人好言他惡其喻若是，唯知彰人之罪，不知自毀其行也。
translation: This shows that people who speak well of others' evil metaphors are like this, knowing only to reveal people's sins but not to disparage their own actions.

source_sentence: （一四）外國小人，事貴人欲得其意，見貴人唾地，競來以足蹹去之。
translation: (14) An ordinary person in a foreign country wants to serve a noble person to get his way, so when he sees that person spitting on the ground, he rushes to wash his feet against him.

source_sentence: 有一人不大健勦，雖欲蹹之初不能得，後見貴人欲唾，始聚口時便以足蹹其口。
translation: There's a man who isn't very strong and bold, but although he wants to bite him, at first he can't, but then he sees that the noble man wants to spit, and when he first gathers his mouth, he uses his foot to bite it.

source_sentence: 貴人問言：「汝欲反耶？
translation: The noble man asks, "Do you want to turn against him?

source_sentence: 何故蹹吾口？」
translation: Why are these words used in my mouth?"

source_sentence: 小人答言：「我是好意，不欲反也。」
translation: The little man replied, "I have good intentions and don't want to oppose them."

source_sentence: 貴人問言：「汝若不反，何以至是？」
translation: The noble man asked, "If you don't want to oppose it, how did you get to this point?"

source_sentence: 小人答言：「貴人唾時我常欲蹹唾，唾纔出口眾人恒奪，我前初不能得，是故就口中蹋之也。」
translation: The little man replies, "I always want to spit when you spit, but when I first spit, people always take it away from me, so I just smash it in my mouth."

source_sentence: 此喻論議時，要須義出口然後難也。
translation: When discussing this metaphor, it's difficult only when the meaning is expressed.

source_sentence: 若義在口、理未宣明便興難者，喻若就口中蹋之也。
translation: If someone raises a difficulty before the meaning is explained in words, it's a metaphor for throwing it in the mouth.

source_sentence: （一五）昔佛與諸弟子，入舍衛城欲乞食，道邊見有一坑舉城污露，諸不淨物悉在其中，見一老母猪將諸肫子，共臥不淨坑中。
translation: (15) Once, the Buddha and his disciples went into the city of Śrāvastī to solicit alms, and at the side of the road they saw a pit that held up the city's filth and in which all the impure things were present.

source_sentence: 時佛微笑現四十齒并出四牙，從四牙中放大光明，遍照三千周及十方，其光明還繞佛身三匝從胸上入。
translation: The Buddha then smiled and showed forty teeth and four tusks, and from those four tusks a bright light radiated out that shone everywhere in the 3,000 and in the ten directions, and that light circled the Buddha's body three times and entered through his chest.

source_sentence: 諸佛之法，說地獄事光從足下入，欲說畜生事光從膊入，欲說餓鬼事光從髀入，欲說人事光從臍入，欲說諸天事光從胸入，欲說聲聞事光從口入，欲說緣覺事光從眉間相入，欲說諸佛菩薩事光從頂入。
translation: The buddhas' teachings say that the light from the affairs of hell enters through the bottom of the feet, that the light from the affairs of animals enters through the shoulders, that the light from the affairs of hungry ghosts enters through the thighs, that the light from the affairs of humans enters through the navel, that the light from the affairs of gods enters through the chest, that the light from the affairs of śrāvakas enters through the mouth, that the light from the affairs of pratyekabuddhas enters through the eyebrows, and that the light from the affairs of buddhas and bodhisattvas enters through the top of the head.

source_sentence: 阿難見光從胸入，知佛欲說諸天事，即時長跪白佛請問其意。
translation: Seeing the light enter through his chest, Ānanda knew that the Buddha wanted to teach the affairs of the gods, so he knelt down long enough to ask the Buddha what he meant.

source_sentence: 佛語阿難：「過去無數劫有一長者，乏無兒息，唯有一女端正殊妙聰明辯慧，其女父母甚愛重之。
translation: The Buddha said to Ānanda, "There was an elderly man in a countless eon in the past who had no children but had a daughter who was correct, exquisite, intelligent, and insightful, and whose parents greatly valued her.

source_sentence: 女年既大，便說一偈問父母言：『一切駛水流，世間苦樂事，本從何處出，何時當休息？』
translation: When she was old enough, she spoke a verse and asked her parents, 'All the currents that flow, the things that are painful and pleasant in the world, where did they originally come from, and when will they come to rest?'

source_sentence: 父母聞之慶其奇雅，不知何言以答此偈。
translation: When their parents heard it, they were delighted by its beauty, and they didn't know what words to use in response to the verse.

source_sentence: 其女欲解此義而不蒙答，便大愁憂不復飲食。
translation: When their daughter's desire to understand its meaning wasn't answered, she became very sad and stopped eating.

source_sentence: 父母見女愁憂，便大恐懅，即時為設大會，請諸婆羅門及多智長老，眾人雲集。
translation: Seeing their daughter's distress, her parents became very frightened and immediately set up a large assembly, inviting Brahmins and elders of great wisdom, and gathering a multitude of people.

source_sentence: 供設既畢，於眾會中施一小床，女坐其上，還說前偈以問眾人，眾人默然無能答者。
translation: When the offerings were made, he made a small bed in the assembly, sat the girl on it, and asked the crowd in the previous verse, but they were silent and unable to answer.

source_sentence: 長者即以七寶盛滿一盤而宣令曰：『其有能答者，以此與之。』
translation: The elder then filled a dish with seven treasures and ordered, 'If there's anyone who can answer, take this and give it to them.'

source_sentence: 時有一婆羅門，形體端正而智慧尠少，貪其珍寶便言：『我能答也。』
translation: Then there was a Brāhmaṇa with an upright body and little wisdom who coveted his treasures and said, 'I can answer that.'

source_sentence: 其女聞之即說偈以問婆羅門，亦不解此偈義之所歸，直言：『此事都無所有也。』
translation: When the woman heard this, she asked the brāhmaṇa in verse, but she didn't understand the meaning of the verse and said, 'This matter is completely nonexistent.'

source_sentence: 女即思惟，即得無所有定，便自唱言：『此真大師益我不少。』
translation: The woman then reflected on that, and she attained the concentration of nothingness. She then said to herself, 'This is really a great teacher who's helped me a lot.'

source_sentence: 女後命終上生無所有處，過四十劫，盡彼天壽來生此間。」
translation: At the end of her life, she'll go up to a place where nothing exists, and after 40 eons, she'll finish her life in that heaven and come back to this place."

source_sentence: 爾時長者女者，此老母猪身是也，天福已盡宿命罪至，於此世受猪形也。
translation: At the time, the elder woman, who was in the body of this old sow, had ended her past life of merit in heaven and was condemned to take the form of a pig in this world.

source_sentence: 此女本說偈問時，若遇明師即可得道；此女雖行禪定無有智慧，定報既終還墮惡道也。
translation: When this woman originally spoke in verse and asked questions, she could have attained the Way if she'd met a wise teacher; although she practiced meditation and had no wisdom, the result of that concentration would have been falling back into a bad destiny after ending it.

source_sentence: （一六）昔有一大國王，身得重病十二年不差，一切大醫無能治者。
translation: (16) Once, there was a great king who was seriously ill for 12 years, and no great physician could treat him.

source_sentence: 時邊方小國統屬大王，有一醫師善能治病，王即召來令治己病，未久之間即蒙除降。
translation: At the time, a small country in a neighboring region was under the rule of a great king, and there was a physician who was so skilled at treating illnesses that the king summoned him to treat his own illness, and he was freed and delivered before long.

source_sentence: 王便念欲報此師恩，屢遣使者宣令彼國：「此師治王病差，應有大功宜應賞賜，象馬車乘牛羊田宅青衣直人嚴飾之具，皆給與之。」
translation: The king then remembered that he wanted to repay this physician's kindness, and he often sent envoys to that country to tell them, "This physician should be given a reward for his great work in treating the king's illness, such as elephants, horses, chariots, cattle, sheep, fields, homes, green clothing, and ornaments for straightforward people."

source_sentence: 彼小國王奉宣上命，為設舍宅高堂重閣，給其師婦衣裳飲食珠環嚴具，及象馬牛羊一切備足。
translation: The king of that small country was ordered by Hōshō to build a mansion, a high hall, and a heavy pavilion, and to give his teacher and his wife clothing, food, drink, jewelry, and an ornament, as well as elephants, horses, cattle, and sheep.

source_sentence: 師在王邊無有語者，師便思惟：「我治王病大有功夫，未知王當報我與不？」
translation: When the teacher was at the king's side, no one said anything, so the teacher thought, "I've done a great job treating the king's illness; I wonder if the king will reward me for it?"

source_sentence: 復經數日王轉平復，其師請辭欲還本國，王便聽之，給一羸馬乘具亦弊。
translation: After several more days, the king recovered, and his teacher asked to be excused and wanted to return to his homeland. The king then complied, giving him a worn-out horse and its equipment.

source_sentence: 師大歎恨：「我治王病大有功夫，而王不識恩分不相料理，令我空去。」
translation: The teacher greatly regretted, "I've done a great job treating the king's illness, but the king didn't recognize my part in his kindness and didn't take care of it, leaving me in vain."

source_sentence: 循道愁歎以為永恨。
translation: Following the path, he was sad and praised for his eternal hatred.

source_sentence: 適至本國見有群象，問象子曰：「此誰家象？」
translation: When he arrived at his native land, he saw a herd of elephants and asked Elephant Boy, "Who are these elephants?"

source_sentence: 象子答曰：「此是某甲師象。」
translation: The elephant replied, "This is the elephant of certain Jia's teacher."

source_sentence: 復問象子曰：「某甲師何從得此象？」
translation: Again, he asked the elephant son, "How did that certain Kāśyapa teacher get this elephant?"

source_sentence: 象子答曰：「某甲師治大王病差，功報所得也。」
translation: The elephant replied, "Some master healed the king's illness, and it was a reward for his efforts."

source_sentence: 小復前行見有群馬，問馬子曰：「此誰家馬？」
translation: Again, Xiao went ahead and saw a herd of horses. He asked Muzi, "Whose horses are these?"

source_sentence: 馬子答曰：「某甲師馬。」
translation: The horse replied, "Some guy is a mentor and a horse."

source_sentence: 小復前行見有群牛羊，問群牛羊子曰：「此誰家牛羊？」
translation: Again, Xiao went ahead and saw a herd of cattle and sheep. He asked the herd, "Whose cattle and sheep are these?"

source_sentence: 羊子答曰：「某甲師牛羊。」
translation: The sheep replied, "Some guy is the master of cattle and sheep."

source_sentence: 小復前行見其本舍高堂重閣殊異本宅，問門人曰：「此是誰舍？」
translation: Xiao went further and saw that his home was a high hall with a high pavilion that looked different from his original home, and he asked the gatekeeper, "Who is this home?"

source_sentence: 門人答曰：「此是某甲師舍。」
translation: The gatekeeper answered, "This is the residence of a certain master."

source_sentence: 便入其閤內，見其婦形色豐悅身服寶衣，怪而問曰：「此誰夫人？」
translation: He then went inside his hut and saw a woman with a handsome appearance and wearing a jeweled robe. He wondered, "Who is this wife?"

source_sentence: 直人答言：「此是某甲師夫人。」
translation: The intuitive man replied, "This is the wife of a certain Jia Shishi."

source_sentence: 從見象馬及入舍內，皆知是治王病功報所得，便自追恨，本治王病功夫少也。
translation: From the time he saw the elephant and horse and entered the monastery, he knew it was the result of treating the king's illness and the merits, and he then pursued his own resentment, for he had done little to treat the king's illness.

source_sentence: 喻福德也，福德留難如王病也，醫師喻修福人也，治王病者，喻如行人能修福事也。
translation: It's a metaphor for good fortune, and it's difficult to retain good fortune like the king's illness. The doctor is a metaphor for someone who cultivates good fortune, and healing the king's illness is a metaphor for a practitioner who cultivates good deeds.

source_sentence: 王病差者，如福德已成也，王宣令賞賜象馬室宅者，言福積於此報成於彼也。
translation: When the king's illness is poor, it's like when good fortune has been achieved, and when the king declares that he will reward an elephant, horse, or mansion, it means that the good fortune accumulated here will be rewarded there.

source_sentence: 夫望速者，常患應遲也。
translation: Someone who expects quickly will always suffer from being late.

source_sentence: 如人少信，有時作福便望朝夕報也，老病死至便謂自然無善報也，得天中陰善應具至，如彼醫師見象馬也。
translation: Like a person with little faith who sometimes works to achieve good fortune and then expects rewards in the morning and evening, or who naturally assumes there's no good reward when old age, illness, and death arrive, they'll attain the intermediate aggregate in heaven where goodness is fully present, like that doctor who sees an elephant and horse.

source_sentence: 乘此中陰既到天宮，受彼生陰，目見天堂種種嚴飾，乃知追恨往昔不多作也。
translation: After riding this intermediate aggregate to the heavenly palace and accepting his birth aggregate, he sees the various adornments of heaven and knows that he hates the past for not having done more.

source_sentence: 如彼醫師既見賞賜，恨其治病功夫少也。
translation: It's like that doctor who, having seen the reward, hates himself for his little effort in treating illnesses.

source_sentence: （一七）外國時有惡雨，若墮江湖河井城池水中，人食此水，令人狂醉七日乃解。
translation: (17) In a foreign country, there's bad rain that falls into the water of rivers, lakes, wells, cities, and ponds, and when people eat this water, they become wildly drunk for seven days and then are liberated.

source_sentence: 時有國王多智善相，惡雨雲起王以知之，便蓋一井令雨不入。
translation: When a king with much wisdom and good characteristics knew about the rising of clouds of bad rain, he covered a well so that the rain wouldn't fall in.

source_sentence: 時百官群臣食惡雨水，舉朝皆狂脫衣赤裸，泥土塗頭而坐王廳上，唯王一人獨不狂也，服常所著衣天冠瓔珞坐于本床。
translation: When the hundred officials and ministers eat the bad rainwater, they all go crazy in court, strip naked, smear their heads with dirt, and sit in the king's hall, except for the king alone, who isn't crazy and puts on his usual robes and sits on his native bed with his heavenly crown and jewelry.

source_sentence: 一切群臣不自知狂，反謂王為大狂，何故所著獨爾？
translation: All the ministers didn't know they were crazy, but they said the king was crazy, so why was he alone in his robes?

source_sentence: 眾人皆相謂言：「此非小事，思共宜之。」
translation: The people all said to each other, "This is not a trivial matter; think about it together."

source_sentence: 王恐諸臣欲反，便自怖懅語諸臣言：「我有良藥能愈此病，諸人小停，待我服藥須臾當出。」
translation: Afraid that the ministers might want to oppose him, the king then frightened himself and said to the ministers, "I have a good medicine that can cure this illness; stop there, and wait a moment while I take the medicine."

source_sentence: 王便入宮脫所著服，以泥塗面須臾還出，一切群臣見皆大喜謂法應爾，不自知狂。
translation: The king then went into the palace, took off the clothes he was wearing, rubbed mud on his face, and came back out in a moment.

source_sentence: 七日之後群臣醒悟大自慚愧，各著衣冠而來朝會，王故如前赤裸而坐，諸臣皆驚怪而問言：「王常多智，何故若是？」
translation: When the ministers awoke seven days later, they were greatly ashamed and came to the court dressed in robes and robes. The king was sitting naked as before, and they were all surprised and asked, "The king always has much wisdom; why is it like this?"

source_sentence: 王答臣言：「我心常定無變易也，以汝狂故反謂我狂，以故若是，非實心也。」
translation: The king answered his ministers, "My mind is always stable and unchanging, but you say I'm crazy because you're crazy; therefore, if this is the case, it's not really my mind."

source_sentence: 如來亦如是，以眾生服無明水一切常狂，若聞大聖常說諸法不生不滅、一相無相者，必謂大聖為狂言也。
translation: The Tathāgata is likewise. Because sentient beings subdue the waters of ignorance and are always crazy, if they hear that a great sage always teaches that things don't arise or cease and have one characteristic and no characteristics, they must say that the great sage is crazy.

source_sentence: 是故如來隨順眾生，現說諸法是善是惡、是有為是無為也。
translation: Therefore, the Tathāgata follows sentient beings and now explains whether things are good, bad, acquired, or inactive.

source_sentence: （一八）阿修羅前世時曾為貧人，居近河邊常渡河擔薪。
translation: (18) In a previous life, an asura was once a poor man who lived near a river and used to cross it to carry firewood.

source_sentence: 時河水深流復駛疾，此人數數為水所漂，既亡所持身又沒溺，隨流宛轉急而得出。
translation: When the river was deep and fast-flowing, that person was repeatedly swept away by the water, lost the body he was holding, and became submerged as the current swiftly turned.

source_sentence: 時有辟支佛作沙門形詣舍乞食，貧人歡喜即施，飯食訖已行澡水畢，置鉢虛中飛行而去。
translation: A pratyekabuddha then took the form of an ascetic and went to his house to solicit alms. The poor man was delighted and gave it to him.

source_sentence: 貧人見之因以發願：「願我後生身形長大，一切深水無過膝者。」
translation: Seeing that, the poor man made a vow, "May my body grow so large in my afterlife that I won't be able to reach more than my knees in all deep water."

source_sentence: 以是因緣得極大身，四大海水不能過膝，立大海中身過須彌，手據山頂下觀忉利天。
translation: Because of this cause, he attains a body so large that the four great rivers of water can't reach his knees, and he stands tall in the ocean with his body surpassing Sumeru and looks down at the Heaven of the Thirty-three with his hand on the mountain peak.

source_sentence: 況佛無央數劫積大誓願，法身滿虛何足怪乎？
translation: How much more so when the Buddha has accumulated countless eons of great vow, is it any wonder that the Dharma body is filled with space?

source_sentence: （一九）昔有一國王子，年始七歲，便入深山求學仙道，未曾知朝廷百官之任。
translation: (19) Once upon a time, there was a prince of a country who was seven years old when he went deep into the mountains to train in the ways of immortality, without ever knowing the responsibilities of the court's 100 officials.

source_sentence: 後國王壽終，便無堪任為國王者，群臣共議：「山中仙人本是王子，兼修道德，以此為王，萬國有賴也。」
translation: When the king's life ended, there was no one qualified to be king, but the ministers agreed, "The sage in the mountain was originally a prince who also cultivated morality.

source_sentence: 率土臣民皆出詣山，拜此仙以為國王，乘以王輿迎還本國，宣勅食官妙饌盛味以饗大王。
translation: They led their subjects to the mountain, worshipped the sage as king, returned to their home country on the king's mule, and announced that the food officials would serve the king a delicious meal.

source_sentence: 王以食味可口故，其餘諸物事事從厨士索之，群臣具皆笑，故謂王曰：「百官之任各有所主，厨官自主食、衣官自主衣，兵事寶藏各有所司，不可以食美故責備一人也。」
translation: Because the food was so delicious, the king asked the cooks for everything else, and the ministers all laughed, so he told the king, "Each of the hundred officials has his own director, the cooks have their own food, the clothiers have their own clothing, and the soldiers have their own treasures, so you can't blame one person for the beauty of the food."

source_sentence: 此喻明眾經各自有所明，不可責備於一經也。
translation: This metaphor shows that each of the sūtras has something to teach, and it's not possible to blame one scripture for another.

source_sentence: 彼若自明諸法實相，阿毘曇明諸法有，各各相異，勒相、無相而說也。
translation: If they themselves explain the true characteristics of dharmas, the abhidharma explains that dharmas exist and differ from each other, and it's explained in terms of lemmas and formlessness.

source_sentence: （二〇）鹿林昔有五百群鹿，在此林中有鹿王，一是菩薩，一是真鹿王。
translation: (20) There once was a herd of 500 deer in a deer park, and in this park there was a deer king, one a bodhisattva and the other a true deer king.

source_sentence: 時有國王出城獵，見此群鹿引兵圍之，彼二鹿王共設方計，俱詣人王長跪白人王言：「今在王界分受屠割，若王一時併殺諸鹿，噉不時盡或臭爛，意欲日送二鹿以供王食，餘者次第當日日奉送不敢有闕也。
translation: When a king went out to hunt in his city and saw this herd of deer and led an army to surround them, the two deer kings planned together, went to the king of men, knelt down long, and told the king himself, "Now, we're here at the king's border, and we're being slaughtered, so if the king kills all the deer at once and their gnawing is not exhausted or they smell bad, he wants to send two deer to the king to eat every day, and he'll send the rest in turn, so he won't dare to miss them.

source_sentence: 願王見聽，小得延命，此豈是非大王之恩耶？」
translation: May the king see and hear this, and may his life be prolonged for a little while, is this not a kindness from the great king?"

source_sentence: 於是人王聽如所白，開圍放之。
translation: Hearing what he had told them, the king of men then opened the pens and released them.

source_sentence: 從此以後，彼二鹿王，自相料簡遂為次第，日送二鹿詣王厨下。
translation: From then on, those two deer kings took it upon themselves to send two deer to the king's kitchen every day in order of their expectations.

source_sentence: 更數日後，有一妊身鹿次應就死，彼鹿詣其王所求待產竟，彼王報言：「餘鹿次第未至，誰代汝者？」
translation: A few more days later, when an expectant deer was due to die, that deer went to the king to seek permission to give birth, and the king reported, "The other deer hasn't arrived yet in order, so who will take your place?"

source_sentence: 彼鹿便詣菩薩王所，白菩薩言：「我王不仁，不以理恕，今來歸命，願為理之。」
translation: That deer then went to the bodhisattva king and said to the bodhisattva, "My king is unkind and doesn't forgive with reason.

source_sentence: 菩薩鹿王愍其如此，遂便自詣人王厨下，厨士白王言：「鹿王自來詣厨，求代彼妊身之鹿。」
translation: The bodhisattva deer king pitied him for that, so he went down to the human king's kitchen, and the cook said to the king, "The deer king has come to the kitchen himself, asking to take the place of that expectant deer."

source_sentence: 王乃怪之希有，語厨士言：「將彼鹿王來。」
translation: The king then wondered about this rare occurrence and said to the cook, "Bring that deer king here."

source_sentence: 於是鹿王詣人王所，遂向王廣說其意，於是人王信心遂生。
translation: The deer king then went to the human king and explained his intentions to him, and the human king's faith was thus born.

source_sentence: 「禽獸猶尚修德，何況人乎？」
translation: "Even animals can cultivate virtue, so why wouldn't humans?"

source_sentence: 令一國之內永不射獵，以此林野長施群鹿，從是以來遂以鹿林為名也。
translation: He made it so that shooting would never take place in a country, and he gave this forest and fields to a herd of deer for a long time, and so he came to be known as Deer Park.

source_sentence: （二一）昔有一居士，其婦妊身，請佛到舍供養畢，欲令如來占其妻後生子欲知男女。
translation: (21) Once, there was a householder whose wife was expecting a baby and invited the Buddha to his abode to make offerings to her, wanting the Tathāgata to find out whether his wife would give birth to a son or a boy.

source_sentence: 佛言：「後當生男，端正殊好，及至長大，當於人中受天上樂，後當得羅漢道。」
translation: The Buddha said, "A son will be born, correct and beautiful, and when he grows up, he'll be among men and enjoy the pleasures of heaven; later, he'll attain the path of the arhat."

source_sentence: 居士聞之心疑不信，後復請六師供養畢，復令占之，居士語六師言：「前使瞿曇沙門占之，言後當生男，不知實為男不？」
translation: After he had invited the six masters to make offerings to him, he was again asked to divine his son. The householder told the six masters, "I asked the Gautama monk to divine his son's birth, saying that a son would be born after him.

source_sentence: 六師言：「當生女。」
translation: The six masters said, "A woman will be born."

source_sentence: 彼六師等憎疾佛法，苟欲相反還自思惟：「若彼生男者，彼居士便當棄我奉事瞿曇。」
translation: Those six teachers hated the Buddha's teaching, and they even thought to themselves, "If that person gives birth to a boy, that householder will abandon me and serve the Gautama."

source_sentence: 便作詭語：「居士！
translation: They then said deceitfully, "Guru!

source_sentence: 君婦當生男，生男之後方大凶禍，家室親屬七世絕滅，以不吉故我前詭言是女也。」
translation: You and your wife will give birth to a son, but after the birth of a son there will be great misfortune and the disappearance of your family for seven generations.

source_sentence: 居士聞之，心用惶怖不知所如。
translation: When the householder heard this, he was terrified and didn't know what to do.

source_sentence: 彼六師等便語居士：「欲得吉利，惟當除去之耳。」
translation: The six masters then told the householder, "If you want to be fortunate, you must remove her."

source_sentence: 六師便為居士婦按腹，按腹欲令落之。
translation: The six masters then pressed the householder's wife's belly and tried to get it to fall out.

source_sentence: 按腹不止，居士婦遂命終，而兒不死，宿命福德故也。
translation: When they didn't stop pressing her belly, the householder's wife's life ended, but her child didn't die because of the fortune of his past lives.

source_sentence: 居士便棄其婦著死人處，大積薪燒之，火焰既盛，佛便將諸弟子就往觀之，居士婦身破壞，便見其兒在蓮花上坐，端正殊好顏貌如雪。
translation: The householder then discarded the woman and put her in the place of the dead man, piled up a large firewood pile, and burned it. When the fire was bright, the Buddha sent his disciples over to look at her, and the householder's wife's body was destroyed, and then he saw his son sitting on a lotus flower with a beautiful, upright face like snow.

source_sentence: 佛命耆域：「取此兒來。」
translation: The Buddha commanded Jīvaka, "Take this child and bring him here."

source_sentence: 耆域即取來，出還本居士，居士遂便長育之。
translation: The Jīvaka then took it and returned it to the householder, who then raised it.

source_sentence: 至年十六才美過人，便廣設多美飲食請彼六師，六師既坐，未久之間便失笑，其人問：「何故笑也？」
translation: When he was 16 years old, he was so beautiful that he invited six masters to his table with a delicious meal.

source_sentence: 六師便答：「吾見五萬里有山，山下有水，有一獼猴落水，是故笑耳。」
translation: The sixth teacher then replied, "I saw a mountain 50,000 miles away, and below it was water in which a monkey had fallen into the water; that's why I laughed."

source_sentence: 此兒知其虛妄，便鉢中盛種種好羹以飯覆上，使人擎與之，餘人鉢中下著飯上著羹。
translation: Knowing this to be false, he put a bowl full of various kinds of good soup, covered it with rice, and had someone carry it for him while the others put rice on the bottom and soup on top of it in their bowls.

source_sentence: 諸人皆食，唯六師獨瞋不食。
translation: Everyone ate it, but the sixth teacher alone was angry and didn't eat it.

source_sentence: 主人問：「何故不食？」
translation: The master asked, "Why didn't you eat?"

source_sentence: 六師答言：「無羹云何食？」
translation: The six masters replied, "Without soup, how can we eat?"

source_sentence: 主人言：「君眼乃見五萬里獼猴落水，何不見飯下羹耶？」
translation: The host said, "Your eyes have seen 50,000 leagues of monkeys falling into the water, so why don't you see the rice and the soup?"

source_sentence: 於是六師大瞋，竟不食而還，徑向尸利求多廣說。
translation: The six masters then became very angry, and they returned without food and went straight to Śrīgupta to explain it to him.

source_sentence: 其人姉與求多作婦，尸利求多聞之亦瞋，告六師言：「瞿曇是彼師，我為大師請來毀辱之也。」
translation: When he heard that, he was also angry and told the six masters, "Gautama is his teacher, and I've invited him here to dishonor him."

source_sentence: 是以作火坑毒飯也。
translation: This is called making a fire pit of poisoned rice.

source_sentence: 此喻極廣，不能一一出，故略舉其要也。
translation: This metaphor is too broad to mention one by one, so I'll briefly summarize the essentials.

source_sentence: （二二）昔有一道士造婆羅門家乞食，婆羅門使婦擎食食之，婦在前立。
translation: (2) Once, a Taoist man went to a Brāhmaṇa's house to solicit alms, and the Brāhmaṇa asked a woman to bring food for him while she stood in front of him.

source_sentence: 其婦端正，道士觀之心便生變，語婆羅門言：「欲味過患出。」
translation: She was so correct that the Daoist's mind changed when he observed her, and he said to the Brāhmaṇa, "A desire for food that tastes like trouble will get you out."

source_sentence: 婆羅門不解，便問言：「何等欲味過患出？」
translation: Not understanding, the Brāhmaṇa then asked, "What is the taste of desire that's more troublesome than escape?"

source_sentence: 道士便抱其婦咽共嗚嗚已，語婆羅門言：「此是欲味。」
translation: The Daoist then embraced the woman and shared a common whimper with her, saying to the Brāhmaṇa, "This is the taste of desire."

source_sentence: 婆羅門大瞋，以杖打此道人一下，道人復語：「此過是患。」
translation: The Brāhmaṇa became furious and struck the Daoist once with his staff, and the Daoist again said, "This is a mistake, and it's a danger."

source_sentence: 復欲重打，道人走到門外，復迴頭語婆羅門：「此是出也。」
translation: When he wanted to hit him again, the practitioner went outside the door and turned around and said to the Brāhmaṇa, "This is what's out."

source_sentence: 喻人不能玄解義味，要須指事然後悟之也。
translation: It's a metaphor for someone who can't understand the meaning in a profound way and needs to point out the facts before they can understand them.

source_sentence: （二三）昔有田舍人暫至都下，見被鞭持熱馬屎塗背，問言：「何故若是？」
translation: (23) Once, a monk from a farm came down to the capital and saw a hot horse with a whip and droppings smeared on its back, and he asked, "Why is that?"

source_sentence: 其人答：「令瘡易愈而不作瘢。」
translation: The man replied, "It makes it easy to heal sores without scarring."

source_sentence: 田舍人密著心中，後歸家語其家人言：「我至都下大得智慧。」
translation: The farmhand clings to his mind, but when he returns home, he says to his family, "I've greatly attained wisdom since I arrived at the end of the city."

source_sentence: 後家人問言：「得何等智慧？」
translation: The family then asked, "What kind of wisdom did he attain?"

source_sentence: 便呼奴言：「持鞭來痛與我二百鞭。」
translation: He then summoned the slave and said, "Bring me a whip and give me 200 painful lashes."

source_sentence: 奴畏大家不敢違命，即痛與二百鞭流血被背，語奴言：「取熱馬屎來為我塗之，可令易愈而不作瘢。」
translation: Fearing the crowd, the slave didn't dare disobey his order, so he gave him 200 painful lashes and bled on his back. He said to the slave, "Bring me hot horse dung and rub it on my back; it will heal easily and prevent scarring."

source_sentence: 語家人言：「汝知之不？
translation: He said to his family, "Do you know this?

source_sentence: 此是智慧。」
translation: This is wisdom."

source_sentence: 此喻下戒道人，本遇明師受戒即得，見他受戒便捐棄本戒，更作白衣以壞法身。
translation: This is a metaphor for a follower of the precepts who meets a wise teacher and receives the precepts, then discards the original precepts when he sees others receiving them and becomes a white-clothed man who destroys the Dharma body.

source_sentence: 喻受二百鞭流血被背也，方求更受如馬屎塗也。
translation: It's a metaphor for someone who's received 200 lashes and been bled on the back, and who then seeks to receive them again like horse dung.

source_sentence: （二四）外國有呪龍師，軍遲盛水詣龍池邊，一心誦呪此龍，即時便見大火從池底起，舉池皆然。
translation: (24) In a foreign country, there was a master who had a spell for a dragon, and when he went to the edge of a dragon pond late in the day with a bowl of water, he recited the spell for that dragon with one thought, and immediately saw a great fire rise from the bottom of the pond and spread it over the entire pond.

source_sentence: 龍見火怖出頭望山，復見大火燒諸山澤，仰視山頂空無住處，一切皆熱逃身無地，唯見軍遲中水可以避難，便滅其火，身作微小形入軍遲中。
translation: Terrified by the fire, the dragon rises up and looks at the mountains, sees another great fire burning the mountains and swamps, looks up at the mountain tops, sees that they're empty and have no place to stay, and that everything is hot and there's no place to run to.

source_sentence: 彼龍池者喻欲界也，所望山澤喻色界也，視山頂者喻無色界也，呪龍師者喻菩薩也，軍遲水者喻涅槃也，彼呪術者喻方便也，大火然者喻現無常，龍大身者喻憍慢也，作小形者喻謙卑也。
translation: That dragon pond refers to the desire realm, the mountain swamp he's looking at refers to the form realm, the mountain peak he's viewing refers to the formless realm, the dragon curse teacher refers to a bodhisattva, the water in Junji refers to nirvāṇa, the spell refers to skillful means, the great fire refers to impermanence, the large body of the dragon refers to conceit, and the small form refers to humility.

source_sentence: 言菩薩示現劫燒欲色洞然，無常大火恐怖眾生，令除憍慢謙卑下下，然後乃悉入涅槃也。
translation: It means that the bodhisattva shows an eon of burning desire, a great impermanent fire that terrifies sentient beings and causes them to remove their pride, humble themselves, and lower themselves, and then they all enter nirvāṇa.

source_sentence: （二五）昔者外國從來久遠，曾有一石當人路側，時為車馬踐蹈小小損減。
translation: (25) Once upon a time, long ago in a foreign land, there was a stone placed on the side of a road that was trampled by carts and horses and slightly damaged.

source_sentence: 彼世有人嫌其妨道，務欲除之，時即打壞。
translation: Some people in that world disliked it as an obstruction to the road and wanted to get rid of it, so they smashed it.

source_sentence: 見有毒蛇從石中出，得風轉大，須臾之間身滿閻浮提。
translation: They saw a viper emerge from the rock, and it got a big breeze that filled Jambudvīpa with its body in a moment's time.

source_sentence: 閻浮提中眾生人物，一日之中悉皆噉盡然後乃死。
translation: All the sentient beings and characters in Jambudvīpa are devoured in a single day, and then they die.

source_sentence: 此是惡報尚速疾如是，況之菩薩本為凡人，積功累德動經塵數之劫，適從發意便成佛道，說法度人而取泥洹，此之利疾豈足怪乎？
translation: How could it be surprising that a bodhisattva who was originally an ordinary person but accumulated merit and transcended innumerable eons should suddenly become a buddha, preach the Dharma to save others, and attain nirvāṇa after accumulating so much effort and virtue, and then be so quick?

source_sentence: （二六）昔有一蛇頭尾自相與諍，頭語尾曰：「我應為大。」
translation: (26) Once, there was a snake whose head and tail were at odds with each other, and the head said to the tail, "I should be great!"

source_sentence: 尾語頭曰：「我亦應大。」
translation: The tail said to the head, "I should be great, too."

source_sentence: 頭曰：「我有耳能聽、有目能視、有口能食，行時最在前，是故可為大；汝無此術，不應為大。」
translation: The head said, "I have ears to hear, eyes to see, and a mouth to eat, and I'm the most advanced when I walk, so I could be great; you don't have this skill, so you shouldn't be great."

source_sentence: 尾曰：「我令汝去，故得去耳，若我以身遶木三匝三日而不已，頭遂不得去求食，飢餓垂死。」
translation: The tail said, "I told you to go, so you could go. If I didn't stop circling the wood three times with my body, the head wouldn't be able to go looking for food, and I'd starve and die."

source_sentence: 頭語尾曰：「汝可放之，聽汝為大。」
translation: The head said to the tail, "You can let him go, and he'll listen to you as the leader."

source_sentence: 尾聞其言即時放之。
translation: Hearing what he said, Tails immediately released him.

source_sentence: 復語尾曰：「汝既為大，聽汝在前行。」
translation: Again, he said to Tails, "Now that you're the great one, I'll let you go ahead."

source_sentence: 尾在前行，未經數步墮火坑而死。
translation: As he walked along, Tails fell into a fiery pit before taking a few steps and died.

source_sentence: 此喻僧中或有聰明大德上座能斷法律，下有小者不肯順從，上座力不能制，便語之言：「欲爾隨意。」
translation: This is a metaphor of a wise and virtuous elder among the saṃgha who's able to cut off the Dharma and a junior who refuses to obey and whom the elder is unable to restrain in terms of strength, so he says, "Do as you like."

source_sentence: 事不成濟俱墮非法，喻若彼蛇墜火坑也。
translation: Not accomplishing anything to help them both fall into illegality, which is like that snake falling into the fire pit.

source_sentence: （二七）昔有捕鳥師張羅網於澤上，以鳥所食物著其中，眾鳥命侶競來食之，鳥師引其網，眾鳥盡墮網中。
translation: (27) Once, a bird-catcher spread a net over a swamp and put food from a bird in it, and many birds' lives competed to eat it.

source_sentence: 時有一鳥大而多力，身舉此網與眾鳥俱飛而去，鳥師視影隨而逐之。
translation: Then, there was a bird that was large and powerful, and it lifted up this net and flew away with the other birds, and the bird-master saw its shadow and chased it away.

source_sentence: 有人謂鳥師曰：「鳥飛虛空而汝步逐，何其愚哉？」
translation: Someone said to the bird master, "How foolish is it for you to fly a bird into space and chase it?"

source_sentence: 鳥師答曰：「不如是告，彼鳥日暮要求拪宿，進趣不同如是當墮。」
translation: The bird master replied, "He didn't tell them, 'That bird asks for a room in the evening, and it goes in a different direction.' He'll fall."

source_sentence: 其人故逐不止，日以轉暮，仰觀眾鳥飜飛爭競，或欲趣東或欲趣西，或望長林或欲赴淵，如是不已須臾便墮，鳥師遂得次而殺之。
translation: That person therefore doesn't stop chasing after them, and as the sun sets, they look up and see the birds flying and competing, either wanting to go east or west, looking toward the long forest or wanting to go to the abyss, and not stopping there, they will fall in a moment, and the bird master then kills them in turn.

source_sentence: 捕鳥師者如波旬也，張羅網者如結使也，負網而飛如人未離結使欲求出要也，日暮而止如人懈怠心生不復進也，求拪不同者如起六十二見恒相反也，鳥墮地者如人受邪報落地獄也。
translation: A bird catcher is like Pāpīyān, a man who spreads a net is like a messenger in bondage, carries a net and flies like a person who's not yet free of bondage and wants to escape its essentials, stops at sunset like a person who's lazy and doesn't regain control, seeks to present themselves differently like someone who's given rise to sixty-two views that are constantly opposed, and a bird that falls to the ground is like a person who's subject to the retribution of evil and falls into hell.

source_sentence: 此明結使塵垢是魔羅網也。
translation: This shows that the dirt of bondage is Māra's net.

source_sentence: （二八）昔佛在世時，有五百力士俱為沙門，共在一處坐禪誦經。
translation: (28) Once, when the Buddha was alive, there were five hundred strong men who were all ascetics and were sitting in one place meditating and chanting sūtras.

source_sentence: 有不善賊盡奪諸沙門衣鉢蕩盡，唯有泥洹僧在。
translation: An unscrupulous thief took all the ascetics' robes and bowls and cleared them out, leaving only the nivāsana saṃgha behind.

source_sentence: 是賊去後，諸沙門輕著泥洹僧，俱詣佛所具白此意，佛語諸沙門言：「汝何不大喚？」
translation: After the thief left, the ascetics despised the nivāsana and went to the Buddha to explain their intentions, and the Buddha said to the ascetics, "Why don't you make a big fuss?"

source_sentence: 諸沙門答言：「佛未聽，是故不敢喚。」
translation: The monks replied, "The Buddha hasn't listened; therefore, I dare not call him."

source_sentence: 佛語諸比丘：「汝若不敢喚者，賊當日剝汝衣，誰當能常給者？
translation: The Buddha said to the monks, "If you didn't dare to call, who would have stripped you of your robes that day and always given them to the thief?

source_sentence: 從今日後，聽汝見賊來時大喚，捉杖塼石恐怖令去，但莫至誠傷害之耳。」
translation: From now on, when you see a thief coming, I want you to shout, grab a staff, stone, and terrorize him, but don't hurt him with your sincerity."

source_sentence: 人之所重者身也命也財也，此三事皆不足惜、不可輕也。
translation: What's important to people is body, life, and possessions, but these three things are not enough to treasure and shouldn't be taken lightly.

source_sentence: 不足惜者，以其非常敗壞無有堅固，愚惑惜之以為我物，貪愛悋惜起不善因緣，後墮惡道，故不足惜也。
translation: They're not enough to treasure because they are highly corruptible and lack solidity, and foolish people treasure them as their own, craving, and stinginess, which give rise to unwholesome causes and later lead to a bad destiny.

source_sentence: 不可輕者，以有身故遇值賢聖，擎跪曲拳承迎禮拜，後得金剛寶身不可毀壞，故曰不可輕也。
translation: 'Not to be despised': It's because they have a body that they meet a good sage, kneel down, bend their fists, welcome them, and venerate them, and then they attain a diamond-body that's indestructible, so they're said not to be despised.

source_sentence: 命不足惜者，人為命故殺生強盜婬妷，口犯四過，心生貪恚邪見，後墮地獄，故曰不足惜也。
translation: A person's life is not enough to treasure because his life is caused by killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, verbal transgressions, and desire, anger, and wrong views in his mind, and he falls into hell later, which is why it's called not enough to treasure.

source_sentence: 而亦不可輕者，以有命故值遇聖賢，得聞法言精義入神盡壽修行，後得寶命無量無窮，故曰亦不可輕也。
translation: But it's not to be despised because life is the reason we meet sages and virtuous men who hear the teaching, speak its essence and meaning, enter the spirit, and train for their whole lives, and then attain precious life that's immeasurable and endless, so that's said to be not to be despised either.

source_sentence: 財不足惜者，以財是五家之分，盜賊水火縣官惡子，五家忽至一旦便盡，故曰不足惜也。
translation: Wealth is not enough to treasure, because wealth is part of the five families, and the five families of thieves, thieves, floods, fires, magistrates, and evil sons are suddenly exhausted once they arrive, so it's said that it's not enough to treasure.

source_sentence: 不可輕者，遇良福田持用布施，種種供養無所遺惜，後得寶財四大藏，周窮濟乏求得無盡，故曰不可輕也。
translation: Those who don't despise it should encounter a good field of merit, make donations, and make various offerings without any loss, and then attain the four great treasures and the four great stores of wealth, which provide endless relief for the poor, so they're said not to despise it.

source_sentence: 夫修福德皆當擬心求成佛道，不應但索人天果報也。
translation: Those who cultivate merit should all intend to pursue the Buddha Way, not just seek the rewards of humans and gods.

source_sentence: 所以者何？
translation: Why is that?

source_sentence: 譬如種穀但求其實，實雖未熟，莖節枝葉自然已得，布施作福亦復如是，發意擬儀但求成佛泥洹之道，道雖未成，人天中樂金輪聖主、帝釋、梵王自然並至，亦如種穀不期莖節枝葉自然而得也。
translation: Just as when you plant grain but only seek its truth, even though the stems, nails, and leaves are naturally present before it matures, so too is it when you give alms and cultivate virtue, when you arouse the intention to plan rituals but seek to achieve the path of nirvāṇa as a buddha, even though the path has yet to be achieved, the bliss among humans and gods that comes naturally from the golden wheel, the noble lord, Indra, and Brahmā, is like planting grain without expecting the stems, nails, and leaves to come naturally.

source_sentence: 所以不應但求人天果報之樂者也。
translation: That's why one shouldn't seek only the pleasure of the rewards of humans and gods.

source_sentence: （二九）昔者天竺有一住處有十萬沙門，五萬餘人已得阿羅漢，六通清徹諸漏已盡，餘有五萬人，或有得下三道者或未得者。
translation: (29) There once was a dwelling place in India that had 100,000 ascetics, 50,000 of whom had attained arhatship and had ended the contaminants by clearing the six supernormal powers, and 50,000 of whom had attained the lower three paths or hadn't yet attained them.

source_sentence: 有一長者欲求人天中福樂自恣，來詣塔廟施設飯食供養眾僧。
translation: An elderly man who wanted to seek the welfare of humans and gods and make his own offerings came to a stūpa to provide food and offerings to the saṃgha.

source_sentence: 時有一上坐得六神通大阿羅漢也，其人極老，鬚白齒落形體枯朽，於十萬人中最為上首。
translation: At the time, there was a great arhat sitting up there who had attained the six supernormal powers, and he was extremely old, his beard was white and his teeth had fallen out, and his body was withered, making him the foremost among the 100,000 people.

source_sentence: 為此長者呪願畢，飲食已竟行澡水訖，便語長者言：「檀越！
translation: After he had finished his vow for this elder and had finished washing his body with water, he said to him, "Don't forget, sir!

source_sentence: 今施方得大罪。」
translation: Now, the donor has committed a great sin."

source_sentence: 於時會中未得道者皆謂：「上座老故出此狂言耳？」
translation: At the time, those who hadn't yet attained the Way said, "Did the senior monk say that crazy thing?"

source_sentence: 上座答曰：「其事實爾，非狂言也。」
translation: The ascended seat replied, "It's true, and it's not crazy talk."

source_sentence: 眾人問言：「此人種福，云何得罪？」
translation: The crowd asked, "This person cultivates merit, so how did he obtain a demerit?"

source_sentence: 上座答曰：「汝等識其一未識其二。
translation: The ascended master answered, "You know the one but not the other.

source_sentence: 此人種福復受人天中樂，於受樂中大生憍慢，自謂為足，不求解脫，覩佛不奉、見經不讀、見沙門無虔敬之心，放逸自恣，食福既盡，當墮惡道無量阿僧祇劫，罪畢乃出，所以得種大罪者，因受世俗大報故也。
translation: This person cultivates merit and then receives the pleasures of humans and gods, becomes very proud of those pleasures, considers himself to be quite satisfied, doesn't seek liberation, doesn't respect the Buddha when he sees him, doesn't read the sūtras when he sees ascetics, doesn't have a sense of reverence when he sees ascetics, and is careless and self-indulgent.

source_sentence: 若擬心聖道而為此福者，後受報時終無此報也。」
translation: If someone intends this merit to be the result of their mind's noble path, they'll never experience this result when they're later rewarded."

source_sentence: （三〇）昔天竺國有二貧人，營生計儉常賣酪自存，二人各頭戴酪瓶詣市欲賣。
translation: (30) Once there were two poor people in India who lived a frugal life and always sold cheese to save themselves.

source_sentence: 時值天雨道路泥滑，一人有智自思惟言：「今日泥雨道路難行，我或傾倒瓶破失盡，今並出酥，若我當倒所失無幾。」
translation: When it rained and the road was muddy, one had the wisdom to think to himself, "Today, the mud and rain make it difficult to navigate, so I might tip the flask and lose all of it; now, if I were to tip it, I wouldn't lose much."

source_sentence: 一人少智全持詣市，中路泥滑二人俱倒，一人愁憂涕泣宛轉臥地，一人都無愁色亦不懊恨。
translation: One person with little wisdom fully carried to the marketplace, and when the mud in the road became slippery and they both fell down, one person became sad and wept, and one person turned around and lay down on the ground, but neither looked sad nor resented it.

source_sentence: 有人問言：「汝等二人酪瓶俱破，所失亦等，彼此無異，何故一人獨愁涕泣懊恨，一人靜然都無恨色？」
translation: Someone asked, "You two have both broken vials of cheese and lost the same amount, and there's no difference between them, so why is one person alone sad and weeping and feeling resentful and another person calm and without a look of resentment?"

source_sentence: 一人答曰：「我所持酪都未出酥，今日瓶破所失蕩盡，是以懊恨不能自勝。」
translation: One person replied, "None of the cheese I was holding had yet to yield ghee, and now that the jar has broken down and all that's lost, I'm sorry and can't bring myself to hate it."

source_sentence: 一人答言：「我所持酪先已出酥，今瓶雖壞所失無幾，是以坦然無所恨也。」
translation: A person replies, "The cheese I was holding had already come out of the ghee, and even though the jar has broken down today, there's not much left, so I'm calm and have no resentment."

source_sentence: 瓶喻身也，酥喻財物也。
translation: The bottle is a metaphor for the body, and the ghee is a metaphor for possessions.

source_sentence: 有人慳貪悋惜財物，貪求現利不念非常，身瓶頓壞財物失盡。
translation: When someone is stingy and greedy with their possessions and covets present gain without thinking about the extraordinary, their body and vial suddenly break down and their possessions are lost.

source_sentence: 喻若彼人忘失酥酪，懊惱追恨悔無所及。
translation: It's a metaphor for someone who forgets the butter and cheese, and who feels remorse and regrets that there's nothing they can do.

source_sentence: 有人深信後世果報，所有財物並用惠施，身瓶雖壞喪失無幾。
translation: Although someone is convinced of the consequences in the later life, they give generously of all their possessions and goods, but they lose little of what they have even though their body and vase have broken down.

source_sentence: 亦如彼人酪瓶雖壞所失甚少，其心坦然無所追恨。
translation: Similarly, even though that person's vial of cheese breaks down, he loses very little of it, and his mind is straightforward with no remorse.
